revision.text:
{{for|the darts player|Andy Parsons (darts player)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Andy Parsons | image = Andy Parsons Glastonbury 2013.jpg | caption = Parsons at the [[Glastonbury Festival 2013]] | pseudonym = | birth_name = Andrew John Parsons | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1967|4|03|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]], [[Dorset]], [[England]] | death_date = | death_place = | medium = Stand-Up | nationality = British | active = 1992–present | genre = Satire | subject = | influences = Peter Cook{{cite newspaper |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/may/06/andy-parsons-on-peter-cook-the-pure-filth-that-inspired-my-career#comment-51614453 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 May 2015 |title=Andy Parsons on Peter Cook: the pure filth that inspired my career |last=Parsons |first=Andy }} | influenced = | spouse = | notable_work = ''[[Parsons and Naylor's Pull-Out Sections]]'' (2001–07)
''[[Mock the Week]]'' (2005–2015) | education = Law | alma_mater = [[Christ's College, Cambridge]] | signature = | website = {{official website|http://www.andyparsons.co.uk}} | footnotes = }} '''Andrew John Parsons''' (born 3 April 1967){{cite web|title=Andy Parsons|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/a/322/andy_parsons|work=Chortle|accessdate=3 August 2011}} is an English comedian and writer. He regularly appeared on ''[[Mock the Week]]'' from Series 3 to Series 14. With comedy partner [[Henry Naylor]], he has written and presented nine series of ''[[Parsons and Naylor's Pull-Out Sections]]'' for [[BBC Radio 2]]. ==Early life== Parsons was born in [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]], [[Dorset]].{{cite news|title=What's on: Andy Parsons' Gruntled |url=http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/leisure/8952998.What_s_on__Andy_Parsons__Gruntled/ |work=The Westmorland Gazette |date=4 April 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319223512/http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/leisure/8952998.What_s_on__Andy_Parsons__Gruntled/ |archivedate=19 March 2012 |df=dmy }} He attended Parc Eglos Primary School, [[Helston]] Comprehensive School in [[Cornwall]] and [[Churston Ferrers Grammar School]], [[Torbay]] (Devon){{cite web|url=http://www.thisisnorthdevon.co.uk/Parsons-reveals-West-Country-roots/story-12160614-detail/story.html|title=Andy Parsons reveals his West Country roots|publisher=North Devon Journal|date=12 March 2009|accessdate=12 August 2011}} before going to [[Christ's College, Cambridge]] to study Law,{{cite web|title=Christ's College – Alumni|url=http://www.christs.cam.ac.uk/alumni/distinguished-alumni/|publisher=[[Christ's College, Cambridge|christs.cam.ac.uk]]}} where he met and formed a [[double act]] with [[Henry Naylor]] which twice toured with the National Student Theatre Company and once with the [[Footlights]]. After completing his studies, Parsons got a job working as a legal clerk on a case at the [[Greenock]] [[shipyard]]s, which he describes as "the most tedious thing I'd ever done."{{cite news|title=What's on leisure – Andy Parsons|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Whats-on-leisure/Choice/Andy-Parsons.htm|publisher=[[Cambridge News]]|date=12 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104234015/http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Whats-on-leisure/Choice/Andy-Parsons.htm|archivedate=4 November 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://old.chortle.co.uk/radio/radiofeatures/parsonsnaylor.html|title=Doubled up: Parsons and Naylor's comedy careers|work=Chortle|date=6 July 2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928214240/http://old.chortle.co.uk/radio/radiofeatures/parsonsnaylor.html|archivedate=28 September 2007}} With Naylor he established TBA, London's first sketch comedy club.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/parsonsandnaylor/|title=Parsons And Naylor's Pull-Out Sections|first=|last=BBC|publisher=}} ==Writing/Television== His first TV writing job was for ''[[Spitting Image]]'' and he went on to become one of the main writers. He has also appeared as a guest on ''[[They Think It's All Over (TV series)|They Think It's All Over]]'', ''[[QI]]'', and [[BBC Radio 5 Live]]'s ''[[Fighting Talk]]''. Parsons left ''Mock the Week'' in October 2015 after nine series as a regular panelist, missing only five episodes. He, like the other regular panellists on ''Mock the Week'', kept the same seat throughout the series, Parsons being the one on host [[Dara Ó Briain]]'s left. He has also presented The ''PMQ'' show on [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] and was a regular during the 2010 World Cup on the [[BBC Radio 2]] show ''Never Write Off The Germans''. Parsons also appeared in ''World's Most Dangerous Roads'' alongside [[Ed Byrne (comedian)|Ed Byrne]], travelling along the Road of Bones in Siberia, visiting the coldest inhabited place on Earth and sleeping in a tent at -53°c. After writing for ''[[Week Ending]]'', Parsons and Naylor were offered their own show ''[[Parsons and Naylor's Pull-Out Sections]]'' in 2001. They have also performed live versions of the show at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] (1993–2001) and at international comedy festivals in Sydney (1998/99), [[Melbourne]] and [[Adelaide]] (both 1998). ==Stand-up comedy== [[File:Andyparsonsoutsidetheboxjpgcrop.jpg|thumb|right|Parsons in 2007.]] Parsons regularly performs solo shows at comedy festivals, and also at [[The Comedy Store, London|The Comedy Store]]. He is the ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]]'' Comedy Award Winner 2002. In 2008, he co-wrote and starred in a [[BBC Radio 4]] sitcom called ''The Lost Weblog of Scrooby Trevithick'' and a second series, ''Scrooby Trevithick'', aired in 2010. He toured in the UK with his show ''Andy Parsons: Citizens!'' in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2007/05/11/5315/parsons_lands_r4_show|title=Parsons lands R4 show : News 2007 : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide|first=Powder Blue Internet Business|last=Solutions|website=www.chortle.co.uk}} The show was recorded at the [[Lyric Theatre (London)|Lyric Theatre]], London on 28 September 2009 and released on DVD in November that year under the title ''Britain's Got Idiots'' which was shown on BBC2 in October & December 2010. In 2010, Parsons took part in ''[[Channel 4's Comedy Gala]]'', a [[Benefit concert|benefit show]] held in aid of [[Great Ormond Street Hospital|Great Ormond Street Children's Hospital]], filmed live at the [[The O2 Arena (London)|O2 Arena]] in London on 30 March.{{cite web |url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/features/2010/03/31/10770/c4_comedy_gala_at_the_o2,_london |title=C4 Comedy Gala at the O2, London |work=Chortle |author=Chamberlain, Julia |date=31 March 2010 |accessdate=3 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ohZEFqQG?url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/features/2010/03/31/10770/c4_comedy_gala_at_the_o2%2C_london |archivedate=3 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} His 2011 UK National Tour was called 'Gruntled'. and his 2013 tour was called 'I've Got A Shed'. His third DVD 'Slacktivist' was released on 25 November 2013 and was televised on BBC2 in December 2014. His 2015 tour is entitled ''Live & Unleashed - But Naturally Cautious''. {{cite web|url=http://www.andyparsons.co.uk|title=- Andy Parsons|website=Andy Parsons}} Also in 2015 Andy started the Slacktivist Action Group. Occurring monthly with MPs, journalists, experts and comedians.{{cite web|title=SLACKTIVIST ACTION GROUP|url=http://www.andyparsons.co.uk/news/guests-confirmed-for-slacktivist-action-group-october-26th-londons-soho-theatre-7pm-8pm/|website=andyparsons.co.uk}} ==Activism== Parsons is backing [[People's Vote]], a campaign group calling for a public vote on the final [[Brexit]] deal between the UK and the European Union.{{cite news| last = Quinn | first = Ben |title=Brexit: MPs from four parties jointly launch push for people's vote campaign|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/apr/15/brexit-mps-from-four-parties-jointly-launch-push-for-peoples-vote|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=16 April 2018 | access-date = 3 May 2018}}{{cite news| last = Coulter | first = Martin |title=Brexit: Patrick Stewart, Andy Parsons, Anna Soubry, Chuka Umunna and Layla Moran launch campaign for 'People's Voice' referendum on final EU deal|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/antibrexiteers-patrick-stewart-andy-parsons-anna-soubry-chuka-umunna-and-layla-moran-launch-campaign-a3814376.html|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|date=15 April 2018 | access-date = 3 May 2018}} ==Stand-Up DVDs== *''Britain's Got Idiots Live'' (23 November 2009) *''Gruntled Live 2011'' (14 November 2011) *''Slacktivist Live'' (25 November 2013) *''Live and Unleashed but Naturally Cautious'' (27 November 2015) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.andyparsons.co.uk}} * [http://www.chortle.co.uk/shows/edinburgh_fringe_2004/a/1476/andy_parsons%3A_eay_my_satire%21# Review of ''Eat my Satire''] * {{IMDb name|id=0663773|name=Andy Parsons}} *
